PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrount in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.

The mail steamers Dakehlieh and Kossier leave Suez alternatly on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah; continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED
Editor and Manager - R. SNELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF
THURSDAY, JUNE 20, 1907

div.head: THE YEMEN SITUATION
div.p: The recent report that Medina is threatened by the Wahabi leader, Ibn Saud, is of special interest in view of the dangerous situation of the Turkish Army in the Yemen, where Ahmet Faizi Pasha's situation is described as very dangerous. The Wahabis of Nejd first attained notoriety or fame in the last years of the eighteenth and the first two decades of the nineteenth century, during which they conquered the whole of Arabia, sacked Kerbela Nejefand Meshed Ali in Mesopotamia, and levied tribute on the cities of Damascus and Baghdad. Checked by Mohamed Ali they were finally conquered after groat efforts by Ibrahim Pasha who took Dereyeyah in 1828, and left garrisons in the Nejd. In 1840 however the Egyptian and Turkish garrisons were expelled and the dynasty of the Sauds restored, Feysul the chief of the house ruling Nejd, Muteyr, Hail, Jebel Shammar and the Jowf, with territories in Al Hasa near the Persian gulf. In the early sixties the Sauds found a powerful rival in the Bedouin Emir Mohamed ibn Rashid who after winning independence for Hail and Jebel Shammar finally subjected Itiadh, and for nearly 30 years ruled a large state in central Arabia with a tolerance to which the Wahabis were strangers and with a severity that terrified even the zealots of Riadh.

His relations with the Sultan were friendly if distant and it was only when his nephew Abd el Aziz ibn Rashid succeeded him that the Bedouin power began to totter. Early in the nineties, Abd el Aziz son of Feysul of the house of the Sauds rose against the Shammar overlords of Riadh and restored the Wahubi kingdom. The new ruler of Riadh married his sister to the energetic Sheikh of Koweit, Mubarak ibn Sabah and aided by him made frequent raids on Hail. These attacks were at times successful and at times were repulsed, and it was not till 1904 that the Wahabis won a decisive success and captured Hail from the Shammar. But the very completeness of their success brought about the interposition of a new factor in central Arabian politics. Faizi Pasha marched to Hail from Meshed Ali, a Turkish army threatened Koweit and provoked a British naval demonstration and the Wahabis retired. But they retired only 'pour mieux sauter'. Hail was attacked after Faizi Pasha's departure, and Abd el Aziz ibn Rashid died a violent death, in battle according to some accounts, at the hands of conspirators according to others, and was succeeded by his nephew Mutaab who after some fighting made a truce with the Wahabites.

But in the early spring of this year Mutaah was murdered by his cousin who demanded Turkish aid against Ibn Saud who attacked him and was apparently repulsed. The Turks however were quite unable to spare men for campaigns in the wildernesses of Central Arabia, the Wahabis gained ground and according to the latest news are threatening Medina.

At the same time it must not he imagined that the Wahabis are working for the Imam of the Yemen. The Yemen rebels are Zaidis, of pronounced Shiah tendencies, while the Nejdis are Waluihis i.e. Mohammedan puritans, who are the spiritual descendants of Kharejites and the Carinathiaus. Any cooperation therefore between them can only be purely temporary, for assuming the possibility of the loss by the Sultan of the Holy Places, it is quite inconceivable that the Wahabis would consent for one instant to their occupation by heretics while the Yemenis would certainly make a bold bid for their possession.

Here we may refer for a moment to our contemporary the "Egyptian Standard." It is not often that we are agreement with that organ, hut we concur with the writer of an article headed by the title 'The Senoussi Tribe and the Slave Trade" who expresses his surprise at the portentous ignorance of a contributor to "Pearsons Weekly" which published a comic ally inaccurate account of the 'Port of Midi.' the centre of tho slave trade (a port which appears to be quite unknown to map makers and navigators) and of the oases of 'Aziat' and 'Negila.' Aziut may be Lagator Lajiat, a small Tripolitan oasis, while Negila must be Aujilo, an oasis between Tripoli and Jerabub (Jaghbub) which according to Rolilfs, who went there, is a small trade centre and oasis with perhaps 15,000 inhabitants. The Berliers of Aujila and Jalo are indeed accused of indulging in the purchase and resale of slaves, hut the Senoussi sect, while it very probably docs not forbid the traffic, is by no means identified with it according to the judgment of competent authorities. The Jehad preparations of the Senoussi has often been described hut the fact that, with a single exception, the action between the Senoussi and a French force in Wadai in 1905, no collisions have occurred between them and the European powers represented in N. Africa, makes us a trille sceptical of the veracity of the publicists who delight in "making our flesh creep."

div.p: We have received a parcel of magazines from Mr. H. W. Tite which we have forwarded to Gedge Pasha for the Red Sea Lighthouse keepers.

div.head: Port Said Delegation
div.p: The Ministry of Justice has decided to erect a new building to house the mixed delegation at Port Said as their present building lias passed iuto other hands.

div.head: Bubonlo Plague
div.p: 1 admission to hospital at Alexandria, 1 death in and 2 deaths outside hospital at Damanhour and l fresh case at Esneh. were reported during the past 24 hours.

div.head: Matarleh Fisherman.
div.p: A committee has been formed under the presidency of an inspector of the Finance Ministry to consider the claims of the Matarieh fishermen. The committee has arrived on the spot and opened the enquiry.

div.head: Attempted Suicide
div.p: The day before yesterday an Armenian attempted to commit suicide by suffocating himself with gas, but was rescued by one of his family. Financial trouble is suposed to be the cause of the melancholia from which he is suffering.

div.head: Mixed Court of Appeal
div.p: At the General Assembly of the Mixed Court of Appeal, held on the 13th inst., the projected law, relative to the diainage scheme of mosques and zadwiehs, was approved At the same meeting the law. proposed in respect of compulsory registration of births and deaths, was adjourned until after the recess.

div.head: Another Now Company.
div.p: To-day the subscription for the Egyptian Produce and Navigation Company Limited opened at 8.30 a.m. and closed at 12.30 p.m. at Cairo. The capital is £100,000 in 24,812 ordinary and 15.040 deferred shares, the latter of 11 each. The directors are K. F. Rem1 Dreux, Louis Causse, Joseph Girard, Mohamed Bey Mahmoud and Renialv Bey.

div.head: Births and Deaths
div.p: During the week ending the 17th June, 487 births of which 4 were of European parentage, were registered in Cairo. 837 deaths were also reported, of which -17 were European. Hut of the 837 deaths, 6157 were children of less than 5 years of age. Diphtheria, typhus, typhoid, erysipelas and fever are the causes of death cited in the majority of cases, but 90 deaths were due to measles.

div.head: Tho Worlds Cotton Supply.
div.p: Messrs. Neill Brothers in a circular just issued estimate that the world's stock of cotton amounted on June 7th to 5,370,1100 hales, an increase of 1,204,100) hales on the total in June 1904 5. This visible and invisible supply is sufficient for the consumption of American cotton in Europe and America for 22 weeks or up to the middle of November ) against a supply for l8 weeks last year, and about 20 weeks in 1904-5.

div.head: Disaster In Greece.
div.p: A telegram from Athens was received at Alexandria yesterday by the Greek journal "Byzantios," announcing terrible destruction wrought by a gale at Trikkala in Thessaly. One hundred people have been drowned in the tloods and a thousand houses destroyed. Tiikkala is well known to visitors to northern Greece as it is on the way to the interesting monasteries of Meteorn, and on the high road over the Pindos to Januina. 15,000 drachmae have been voted by the Greek Parliament to relieve the victims.

div.head: Saved from Drowning
div.p: About half past five this morning a Syrian woman went bathing near the Ihrahimieh baths, and after she had gone a short distance out loud shrieks were heard. She had apparently been seized by fright, having got out of her depth. A fishing smack was close by but paid no attention to the poor woman's appeals for help, but she was fortunately saved by the coastguard on point duty. At the place where the woman was bathing there is a strong and dangerous current, and the spot is generally avoided by bathers, who are wont to describe it as a death trap.

div.head: A Shocking Affair
div.p: A Greek girl some months ago, of the name of Exarcliopoulo, went from Athens to enter the service of a well-known Greek trader at Cairo. She soon ceased to write home und her parents became very nnxious as to her whereabouts. The mother at length set out from Athens in search of her child und a few days ago arrived at Cairo. Assisted by tho authorities of the Greek Consulate she at last found the child shut up in a house of a notorious character. The unfortunate girl's mother Inis decided to take action ugainst the keeper of the house, who is at present away on a summer holiday. The Greek Consulate has opened an enquiry.

div.head:
OPINION IN LONDON
SIGNIFICANT STATISTICS.
div.p: The misfortunes of the Alexandria and Cairo Bourses have begun to attract considerable attention among financial circles in London, and the leading newspapers all comment on the deplorable financial crisis through which the Egyptian stock markets are now passing. Last Thursday the London Stock Exchange experienced a spasm of uneasiness owing to a heavy failure in Paris, arriving partly from difficulties in Egypt Seven London brokers were reported to have been hit in consequence. The weakness of Egyptian Bonds testified to to the demoralisation in Paris, and the general weak tonp all round and the fears of further difficulties in the City created general depression. Our London financial correspon dent's remarks on the situation should be noted in the Money Market letter, which will be fourni on another page of to-day's issue. His opinions are supported by the authoritative organs of public opinion in London and a large amount of attention is drawn to the Egyptian Money Market's dolorous situation. The "Times" remarks :

"The condition of affairs in Alexandria will surprise no one who has followed the course of events in connexion with the land and mining (sic) speculation which has been going on there for nearly three years. Owing to the remarkable prosperity of the country the operators for the rise have lmd a longer period of success than prudent and farseeing people thought they would enjoy : but for some time past the banks having relations with Egypt have been preparing for trouble there by reducing the facilities for granting loans on speculative issues as much as possible. During the last few days margins have run of advances granted on a number of securities ; in many cases new cover conld not he provided, and the stock lias been sold. In other cases margins have been kept up lately by pledging Egyptian securities of a character superior to the stocks in which the speculation existed, and the renewed decline of the latter having once more caused margins to disappear, the good stocks have been sold by the hanks, since they were marketable, while the stocks they were brought in to support were not. This is a very usual accompaniment of the breakdown of a speculation. As already men tinned, there appears to have been no actual failure in Alexandria as yet : hut failures are naturally looked for in the conditions now prevailing there."
The "Evening Standard ami St. James's Gazette," of Friday last, says :

"The disturbance of the Egyptian markets, which is having an indirect influence upon our Stock Market, lmd been long expected. The great prosperity which prevailed in Egypt, thanks to the enlightened rule under British control and the high prices recently ruling for cotton, produced a vast development in the formation of local companies, many of which were based upon speculations in laud and buildings. So far did the speculative enthusiasm go, that local operators bought hack from London much of the capital issued here of companies working in Egypt, and in consequence of this fact the present weakness has little direct interest to this uiaiket. There are, however, a powerful group of British banks working in the country which have done very well, ami might he expected to he iiillueiïçed by the events proceeding in Alexandria. Mere again, however, there is little reason foranxiety, as the British hanks have long recognised the dangerous character of the speculation being carried on, andindeed have been loudly blamed in Egypt lor the manner in which they have refused to advance upon many of the local shares. (banks and financial institutions located in the country were found more com plaisant, hut operators are now discovering that loans contracted on these terms have inconveniences attached to them, and much of the liquidation now proceeding results from the extended credit given by institution in which thought to be from the conservative policy of the British banks.

The following comments are from the city article of the "Pall Mall Gazette" of Friday last - "Unpleasant- rumours of failures abroad continue to have their market iulliieuce, and no doubt there will be a certain amount of slnugh taring of weaklings at the t' Vuitinentai bourse centres and elsewhere. In Paris unfortunately there are rumours of graver mishaps, and talk of difficulties involving one of the agents de change is troubling the markets. A "Financial News" correspondent goes even further, and while noting the "hear" attacks and the general liquidation, states that the report was current that two official btokers will have to retire, after being assisted at the Settlement. A big speculator is in trouble, though unfortunately that is the case in other directions also. Thus in Egypt there is much uncertainty and difficulty as a result of the gambling that lias been indulged in by land enthusiasts during the last few years. Reports of a big failure in Alexandria following upon the Cairo troubles, and general concern over the financial position, naturally make for uneasiness. Unfortunately there is a hitch over the big financial relief syndicate that was being formed in Cairo to assist the market position. It is said that the National Bank and several big financiers in Cairo and Alexandria are interested in this syndicate, and the capital will he half a million sterling. The latest information in connection with this important financial movement is that some momentary hitch has occurred, inasmuch as the French hanks have been forbidden to join it, under the lead, so it is rumoured, of the Crédit- Lyonnais.'

A very important fact, which is of extreme significance at the present moment, is to be observed in the returns of the Customs Administration for May. From the 1st January to the 31st to the amount of specie exported from Egypt totalled L.E. 3,059,380, as against L.E. 697,909 during the corresponding five months last year. In other words the excess of specie exported compared with the figures for the corresponding period in 1906 amounted to L.E. 2,361,421. During the past five months specie to the value of L.E. 2,020,103 was exported to England. During the same months in the previous year the exports of specie from Egypt to England only totalled L.E, 458,387. Thus from the beginning of this year to the end ot last month England has taken specie to the value of L.E. 1,561,716 over and above the total taken during the same period in 1906. France's surplus imports of specie from Egypt during the same period amounted to L.E. 46,668 over the total for the corresponding period of last year.
The exports of species to India during the same time totalled L.E. 937,294 as compared with L.E. 75,949 in 1906, a surplus of L.E. 861,345.
The total imports of specie during the first, five months are L.E. 1,498,621 against L.E. 549,932 for the same time last year, an increase of L.E. 946,689.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE-
div.p: The Khedive will return to Alexandria from Mariont tomorrow evening, and on Thursday his Highness will preside over the Council of Ministers and later visit the Abou- el-Abbas School.
On his way to Constantinople his Highness will call at Rhodes to visit his eldest daughter, who is ill.

div.head:
THE NATIVE PRESS
EGYPTIAN PARTIES
div.p: (From "Al Watan")

For the want of a better name those Egyptians who are against the British occupation are known by the name of Nationalists. The name is generally accepted now although it does not convey the real meaning of the anti-British party to those who are. not acquainted with the facts. For tho want of a better name also those who are not against modern reform and are vehemently vociferous in their denunciation of the present regime are known by the name of Liberals. This is likely to he generally accepted also after some time.

The Nationalist party includes the majority of Mohammedans mostly of the illiterate type. Its leaders are in almost every case journalists, solicitors, and discharged employés of the Government. Among its supporters the religious feature predominates with a smattering of young men educated in Europe. The main principle of this party is hatred of England and foreigners in general, hut the leaders have no definite aim in view. Most of them seem to think that if foreign rule could be shaken the future Government of Egypt will he their own monopoly and their gain will be immense.

The liberal party counts among its supporters the enlightened minority of the Mobnmuiedntis, the whole of the Coptic nation with hardly an exception, the residents of foreign descent, und generally every sane Egyptian who has no interest in agitating against the Government of the day, The main principle of this party is the support of the present regime in its policy of reform ami justice, and the pacification of minds which have been fanned to fanaticism by the Nationalist Press. Seeing that their opponents have brought about a financial crisis and will one day bring about a more serious trouble by the seditious agitation which has lasted so long, the Liberals have of late carried the cam paign into the enemy's land and disclosed tho hypocrisy ami misdeeds of their opponents, by a series of articles ami letters in the local Press which has almost silenced those who were not sparing in the use of their vocal chords before this date. We believe that this vigorous attack has gained its purpose and proved to tho world that the shrieking Nationalists of Egypt are not the only party in the country that ought to heard. Thanks to Mohamed Bey Wahid and his friends who initiated the last move the Liberal party has gained much in courage and numbers during the last month.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Egyptian Prince" is due to arrive at Alexandira form Beyrout to-morrow morning.
The S.S. "Creole Prine," with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 18th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 5th July.
The Moss lier "Amasis," sailed from Malta ysterday morning, calling at Tripoli (Barbary), is due here on Monday next, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Moorish Prince with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 10th inst. for Alexandria via Tripoli , and is due to arrive at this port on Tuesday next.

div.head: PLURALITY OF OFFICES
div.p: The following nre questions asked and answered in the House of Commons concerning Egyptian affairs

Mr. John Robertson.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he will state the number of individuals in the service of the Egyptian Government who hold more than one Government appointment ; if so, how many ; on what grounds the plurality of offices is held; and what are the emoluments attaching to each of the posts of such persons.
Sir E. Grey.—The only justification for making such an enquiry would be the presumption that some abuse exists. I am not aware of any justification for it.

div.head: EUROPEAN SCHOOL CURRICULUM.
div.p: Mr. John Robertson.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, seeing that Lord Cromer complains, in his Report for 1904, pages 72, 73, and 1905, page 86, that private primary schools in Egypt copy the Europeanised curriculum of the Government schools, to the prejudice of vernacular education, and whereas it is only by such imitation that private schools can secure for their pupils certificates enabling them to compete for Gov eminent and other employment, be will advise the Egyptian Government to substitute for its present school curriculum a system of teaching and certificates which shall meet the needs at once of the Government service and the Egyptian people.

Sir E. Grey. —The Egyptian Government are fully alive to the educational needs of the country, and are making every effort to meet them. I consider that no useful purpose would be served by the interference of H.M. Government.

div.head: REGISTERED LETTERS
div.p: Mr. John Robertson.—To ask tho Secretary of State Foreign Affairs, why the registration fee for letters' despatched from Egypt to the United Kingdom is 2½d (one p.t.) whereas that for letters despatched from the United Kingdom to Egypt is only 2d.; what was the number of letters registered in Egypt for transmission to the United Kingdom during the year 1906; is the extra charge retained by the Egyptian Postal Administration, or is it divided, and in what proportions between the countries through which registered letters from Egypt to the United Kingdom are transmitted; and whether seeing that the net, revenue of the Postal Department, for the year 1906 is approximately £E.240,000, an increase of £.E.34,000 over the previous year, and is estimated at £E.260,000 for 1907, he will advise the Egyptian Government to equalise the rate of postage between the countries above named.

Sir E. Grey.—I will enquire as to the facts. Reductions of postage are always welcome, but I cannot promise to ask the Egyptian Government to make a sacrifice of revenue without knowing what other considerations may be involved.

div.head: QUALIFICATIONS OF TEACHERS.
div.p: Mr. John Robertson. To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether British teachers in Egyptian Government schools and other British officials attached to the Ministry of Public. Instruction are required to show any proficiency in speaking, reading, and writing current Egyptian Arabic, prior to their appointment ; and if such he the case, how many candidates have so qualified during each of the five years last past ; if they be not required so to qualify until alter their appoint nient, what is the period of probation allowed by the regulations, if any ; when were such regulations introduced : have they a retroactive effect ; how many have passed the tests annually during the last five years ; are those who fail allowed to present themselves again and what number of times, and at what intervals ; and how many such failures have taken place.

Sir E. Grey. The question of the Hon. Member contains seven different questions, some of them of minute detail. I will make a general enquiry as to what knowledge of Arabic is required of the British officials referred to as a condition of their employment, and how this is fulfilled.

div.head: SLAVE TRADE REPRESSION.
div.p: Dr. Rutherford.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, how many British inspectors of the Slave Trade Repression Department in Egypt have been appointed during the years 1905 and 1906, and at what salaries.
Sir E. Grey.—I will enquire.

div.head: THE LOST CAMEL CORPS.
div.p: Mr. Hazleton (Galway N.) Whether he would state the circumstances under which certain members of a camel corps, which loft Bir Natron government post some six weeks ago, lost their way and perished in the desert ; what were the numbers and composition of the corps ; how many men were known to have lost their lives and how many were missing ; and what steps were taken by the responsible authorities to succour and rescue them and to notify the Egyptian public of their fate.

Sir E. Grey.— The latest information in my possession respecting this matter is that No. 2 Company Camel Corps, under Whittingham, left for Bir Natron during February, one section being intended to be stationed there, and another at a post then not. yet selected. It was anticipated that their presence there would serve as a deterrent to any future raiding and counter-raiding. I will make inquiries as to the points raised by the lion, member.

div.head: TRIBUNAL JUDGES.
div.p: Dr. Rutherford,—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, what are the salaries and what is the rate of pension payable to Native and British judges, respectively, officiating in the Egyptian mixed courts and in the Native civil and criminal courts and to the judges of Mohammedan ecclesiastical courts ; when were the salaries of the judges of the Native civil and criminal and Mohammedan ecclesiastical courts fixed; within what period, if at all, and by how much, have they been augmented ; and upon what system are their pensions calculated.
Sir E. Grey, I will enquire.

div.head: STATE OF UM RUS
div.p: Mr. John Harvey, who presided on Tuesday week at the ordinary general meeting of the Mysore Reefs (1905) and Explorers (Limited), held at the offices, 6, Queen-street place, E.C., said that when they looked back to the commencement of the last year they would see that at that time everything looked rose coloured. At that time the Um Rus Mine was making regular returns of gold and seemed in a fair way to soon become a dividend paying concern Later returns had not been so favourable, with the result, unfortunately, that mining operations had been stopped, the board coming to the decision that they would not be justified in continuing to spend the money of the shareholders with little chance of success. Even at the present time there was a large and unit of ore still left in the mine, which was of the value of about lldwt. to the ton, but it unfortunately would not pay to extract it of course, the closing of that mine was a very serious thing to this company, which had such a large interest in it. There had during the past year been several other promising properties brought to the notice of the board, but they needed a large immediate payment, and that was not the view of the directors of this company. The most satisfactory one which had been received was from the Mercantile and General Syndicate (Limited), with reference to a tin concession which the company opened in the Malay Peninsula. Tho prospects there were very favourable, for the deposits were of an encouraging nature, and only a small amount of capital was, he said, needful, mid eventually a company could be formed to provide the funds necessary for the conduct of the operations on a large scale. He moved the adoption of the report.
Mr. Vere H. Smith seconded the resolution, which was carried unanimously.

div.head: EGYPT'S CIGARETTE TRADE
div.p: The cigarette trade of Egypt shows for the month of May a general falling off. The total exports for May 1907 nre 39,922 kilos against 54,367 kilos in May 1906, a decrease of 15,445 kilos, and from the first of January the figures are 188,374 kilos as compared with 297,676 kilos during the same period of last year. The following are the figuras for the various countries :— England 6,526 kilos in May 1907 against 8,564 kilos in May 1906 ; British Mediterranean Possessions 199 against 319; Far East British Possessions 5,106 against 6,031 ; Germany 12,289 against 25,510 ; America 1,181 against 853 ; Austro-Hnngary 4,240 against 4,281 ; Belgium 1,834 against 726; China and the Far East 1,893 against 2,212 ; Denmark 53 against 43; Spain nil against 151 ; Franco 2,685 against 2,311 ; French Mediterranean Possessions 36 against 30 ; Greece 23 against 29 ; Holland 766 against 324 ; Italy 520 against 661 ; Russia 3 against 36 ; Sweden and Norway 680 against 1,806; Switzerland 880 against 457. Other Countries 8 against 22. Increases for the period from January 1 to May 31 of this year, ns compared with the same period of last year, are shown by England of 1,065 kilos ; British Mediterranean Possessions 36 ; Aiuericy'3,823 ; Belgium 1,165; China and the Far East 643 ; Denmark 58 ; France 926 ; French Mediterranean Possessions 50 ; Italy 332 ; Sweden and Norway 1,769 ; Switzerland 1,687. The heaviest falling off is registered for Germany, being 105,121 kilos.

div.head: AFFRAY WITH ITALIANS
div.p: Towards 9 o'clock on Tuesday evening last, a band of Italian roughs, consisting of about 10 persons, stationed themselves in Sharia Clot Bey and proceeded to terrorise the neighbourhood by molesting and insulting pedestrians. Finding their way eventually into Atfet el Soukaria street, Francesco Bertone, one of the hand, without any provocation, savagely attacked a Berberin named Chehata Fallas Ha bashi, inflicting a deep wound in the left side with a knife. Thereupon the villians tried to make good their escape, hut fortunately all were arrested. While being searched, a dangerous looking knife, bearing fresh blood stains, and a handkerchief, also soaking in blood, were discovered in the hat of one named Ugo Forenti. The consular authorities have been communicated with.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Nous rappelons que le Concert d'adieu de A. Serato a lien ce soir au Casino à 9 h. 3/4. ; le magnifique progratnmede ce dernier Concert nous fait présager un triomphal succès et nul doute que tous les admirateurs du célèbre Violoniste, qui nous a procuré de si agréables soi rées, ne se donnent rendez-vous ce soir au Casino.
Jeudi, prochain 27 courant. Premier Bal d'Enfants.

div.head:
EGYPT AND SUDAN XL
BEATEN BY M.C.C
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
London, Thursday.

Yesterday an interesting cricket match was witnessed at Lords. An eleven composed of well-known sportsmen residents in Egypt and Sudan played the M.C.C. The home eleven beat Egypt and the Sudan by 219 runs.
SIR BENJAMIN BAKER
CHARITABLE BEQUESTS
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Thusday
The estate of the late Sir Benjamin Baker is valued at 170,513 pounds. The deceased in his will left nurmerous bequests to various charitable institutions.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir William Garstin will leave Cairo this evening for Alexandria after he has finished the budget proposal for 1908. The adviser will be received by the Khedive before his departure on Saturday.
Chitty Bey will embark for Europe on three months' leave on the 2nd proximo.
Lewa Asser Pasha Adjutant General for the Egyptian Army leaves Khartoum at the end of June During his absence Miralai Matchett Bey will act as Adjutant General and Governor General of the Sudan.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Cairo, will leave oil Saturday next for Europe. Aly Bey Saddik will take his place during his absence. The Governor will bid farewell to the Khedive this evening.
Mimlni Owen Bey, Agent General for the Sudan Government, Cairo will go on leave on the 20th inst. Kaim. Amery Bey will act for him during his absence.

This morning Count Bernsdorff, Diplomatic Agent for Germany, will be received in private audience by the Khedive to take leave of his Highness prior to his departure for Europe and to present Count Bressler Bayaki, the new 1st Secretary of the Agenoy, who will act as Diplomatic Agent during the absence of Connt Bernsdorff.
Lewa Ismail Pasha Sirhank, Undersecretary of State for War, will present the prizes at the Military School on Tuesday next.
Herr von Mold, German Commissioner of the Public Debt, left yesterday for Naples on board the Hohenzollem. He is accompanied by Miss von Mold.
The commissioners of the Public Debt present in Egypt are now Count Vaurineux, the French Commissioner and Senator Adamoli, the Italian Commissioner.
Kaimakam II. C. Potter Bey, Department of Works (Rails and Communications Section), Sudan Government, has been appointed Asst. Director of Works.

Mr. C. Délavai Cobham, C.M.G., Commissioner of Larnacu, Cyprus, since 1879, is retiring from the public service on the termination of his present leave of absence. Mr. Cobham, who is M. A. of University College, Oxford, has been identified with the Government ot Cyprus ever since the introduction of British administration in the island. He has published many translations from and into Turkish and Romaic, and lias also printed privately a bibliography of Cyprus.

The funeral took place at Alexandria this morning of the son of Mr. Gardner, the chief dredging master ot the Admiralty dredgers, now engaged in making the pass at Alexandria. The boy was eight years old and had been suffering from a very severe attack of scarlet fever, to which he suocumbed at 8.30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The funeral was largely attended. Rear Admiral Sir Massie Bloin field, K.C.M.G. Director General of the Porta and Lighthouses Administration, and a number of officials belonging ta that Department were present.

A marriage has been arranged between Captain R.T. Rawson, 5th Pu ailiers, attached to the Egyptian Army, son of Mr. E. Rawson, of Barrowville, Carlow, Ireland, and Miss Prances Cornwallis, daughter of Mrs. Charles Holland, late of 162, Ashley Gardens, London.

Commander Moriondo, Vice President of the Mixed Court of Appeal ; Commander Paulaoci and M. Teherakian, both Judges at the Mixed Tribunals of Alexandria, are embarking to-day for Europe on leave by the Florin Rubbatino mailboat.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'huidh 1/2)
La situation n'est pas changde. C'est tou- jours la faiblesse et la baisse qui predominent. Quant aux affaires, elles sont clairsemdes et de peu d'importance.

De 19 1/2 la National Bank fidchty encore a 19 1/4, les Nnngovich de 18 a 17 sans tran­sactions, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 23 a 22, la Land Bank de 7 1/2 a 7 7/16, la Building de 2 5/8 a 2 1/2, l'Union Fonciere de 4 1/2 a 4 3/8, l'Aboukir de 32 a 30.
Par contre, l'Agricole se maintient a 7 5/8, les Maikets remontent a 23/3, la Banque d'Athenes a 118. et la Banque d'Orient A 117.
Il est bien evident qu'en l'absence presque complete d'echanges, les cours sont en grande partie nominaux.

La Cassa di Sconto continue a flechir. Elle s'inscrit aujourd'hui a 93. Il nous revient que l'Union Bank de Vienne, a laquelle cet etablish s'est adressd pour l'aider A se tirer de la situation aotuelle, a deja fait quelque chose dans ce but. D'autre part, les banques locales sont en pourparlers avec la Cassa di Sconto pour lui venir en aide autant que le permettent les circonstances.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutingny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Lundi 17 Juni.
Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres, que
nous avions laisse it 3 3/4, s'est eleve successivement veudredi passte a 3 7/8 et samedi a 4 pour cent, soit en hausse de 1,4.
Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a baisse avant-hier de 1/8 83 7/8. L'Unifiee

est remontee de 1/4 a 104 1/4. La National Bank a encore perdu 1/4 de livre a 19 1/2, de meme que laDai'ra Sanieh a 13 1/4. L'Agricole a regagne 1/4 a 7 3/4. La Delta Light a ega- lement repris 3/8 a 9 1/2.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a en­core recute de 5 francs a 684 et la Banque d'A- thenes de 6 francs a 116.

Ici, le marche a repris, ce matin, une phy- sionomie convenable, sinon tout a fait regnliere. La seance a bien encore ete ouvertepar un discours, mais court et nullement dans le genre de ceux qui avaient marque lesjouritees de jeudi et vendredi derniers. De plus, ce speech a officiel, prononce par le president interimaire de l'honorable Corporation des agents de change. Stir un ton onctuenx et pa­terae, M. Paul Oziol a engage ces messieurs de la corbeille a ne pas se laisser influencer par les nouvelles pessimistes repandues par les bais- siers sur le compte d'une seciete fonciere et d'un etablissement de banque, nouvelles que le president de la Corporation a declarees po- sitivement fausses. M. Paul Oziol a termine sa harangue par quelques bonnes paroles prechant la concorde etl'union, voire la " cooperation a l'ceuvre commune. "

Nous allions oublier de dire que, d'ordre du Comite, la duree des seances a ete fixee a une heure, au lieu d'une demie. Toutes les opera- rations pratiquees sont de nouveau enregis- trdes. Les teneurs de carnet ont ete finalement exclus de la corbeille jusqu'a nouvel ordre,
etc., etc.

Toutes ces decisions sont diversement com­mentees. Reconnaissons qu'elles n'.emeuvent profondement personne, par suite de leur ca- ractfcre febrile. L'opinion prevaut, d'ailleurs, que le Comite prend decidement trop de mesures hatives. Le calme et la circonspection ne sauraient nuire a aucun interet, pas meme a ceux de la respectable Corporation. Il faudrait autant que possible s'attacher a ne pas res- treindro la liberty des transactions, a ne pas tomber dans l'arbitraire et laisser les choses suivre leur cours naturel, d'autantplus que le fond de baisse est presque attaint et qu'en outre la crise ne frappe plus uniqueroent les Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie, mais s'dtend a tous les marches Strangers.

Le nombre des transactions en registries a ete de 64. La National Bank a cloture a 19 1/2-9/16 apres avoir fait 19 5/8. L'Agricole s'est tenue a 7 5,-8-11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a ramenee a 100 Faction ancienne et 110 la nouvelle, la Banque d'Athenes a 122, la Banque d'Orient a 120.
Le Credit Foncier a ete delaisse a 700; les obligations a lots anciennes sont revenues a 320 et les nouvelles a 268-269. La Daira a re­trograde a 14 et I'Union Fonetere /t 4 1/2.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelires, les Nungovich ont ete cotes 15 ex-coupon. Les Egyptian ont fini it 5 1/16 apres avoir ete traites au-dessus de 5 5/16. Les Excelsior sont tomb?s a2 1/4>
La Delta Land a ete bien tenue a 2. Les Estates ont cloture a £ 1. Les Constructions sont revenues a 0 7/16 et lesOnsis a 0 7,16-1/2.
Nous detachons d'une correspondance de Londres, en date du 9 Juin, le passage suivant :

" La situation du marche monetaire n est pas satisfnisante. On remarque trop d'exporta- tions d'or, et l'argent au lendemain est cher et difficile. Les Banques " ramassent '',a Paris surtout, par suite de la toumure inquietante que prennent de Russie.

" Au Stock Exchange, les transactions sont presque nulles en presence de la chert? de l'argent. Les capitalistes en quite de place­ments continuent a rester a l'ecart; seuls les baissiere sont en plein dans leur ?l?ment. L'inquietude et le malaise sont partout ; on s'attend a une bien mauvaise liquidation et a des chutes provoquees par les r?centes fail- lites. "
L'assemblie generale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. sera tenue au Caire samedi prochain, 22 Juin courant, a 4 h. p.m., a la National Bank of Egypt.

A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil d'ad- ministration ; presentation des comptes et bilan de l'exercice clos le 31- Mars 1907 ; fixa­tion du dividende ; election d'adininistrnteurs, etc. Le depot des titres doit etre effectur deux jours avant la date fixie pour l'assemblee.

Du rapport du conseil d'administration, qui vient d'etre publie, il resulte que la situation de la Societe est vraiment tris promettante. A la cloture de l'exercice ecoule, les proprietes de la Delta Land au Caire, Helouan, Tantah, Mansourah et divers autres centres de l'inti- rieur comprenaient unesuperficie de 1,561,699 metres carris, revenant a la somme de L.E. 179,055, sur laquelle la Societe n'a plus a payer que L.E. 28,258, total des montants non echus.
La Compagnie a, en outre, des participa­tions avec des tiers dans d'importantes ac­quisitions de terrains au Caire et en province.
Les benefices nets pour Fannie se montent a £ 35,540. Le conseil propose le paiement
d'un dividende de 3 sh. par action.
L'assemble general ordinaire de l'Egyptian Hotels-Oo. est convoquee au siege social a Londifes pour le ler Juillet prochain.
A l'ordri du jour : rapport do conseil d'ad- inisttion approbation des comptes etbilan l'exercice ecoule; fixation du dividende.
Le depot des titres en Egypte doit etre effect
tue, sept jours avant la date de l'assemblee a
la National Bank- of Egypt, A l'Anglo-Egj-pt'n'Bank ou A la Societe Generate Egyptienne.
Les cours du coton en Amerique sont ren-
seign's en hausse. Depuis vendredi passe, le Juillet a gagne 22 points a 11.61 et I'Octobro
11 points a II 41. Le disponible a, par contre,
reactionne de 25 points a 12 90.
Les arrivages a New-York, pour les deux
derniers jours de la semaine, ont ete de 11,000
balles contre 9,600.
Liverpool a cloture samedi a 6.65 et 6.37
contre 6.66 et 6.40 la veille.
Ici, le marche a ete, avant-hier, soutenn sur
lies achats du commerce. Le Juillet, qui avait
fini a 20 1/4, a ouvert ce matin a 20 3/32pour
cloturer A 20 1/8. Le Novembre, qui etait reste
A 20 1/32, a debute aujourd'hui a 19 7/8 pour
terminer A 19 31/32-20.

div.head:
WINE TRADE CRISIS
SITUATION SERIOUS
TROOPS OCCUPY MONTPELLIER.

div.p: Chamber of Deputies. M. Clemenceau announced that the time hail come to assert the supremacy of the law in the South, Warrants had been issued for the arrest of the principal rebels. He demanded the adjournment of the debate on the Government's conduct, which the Chamber voted by 412 votes to 158.
M. Ribot, urging the support of the Govern ment, said that the situation was the most serious since 1870.

Trains full of troops are passing through Toulouse all day and night en route for the disturbed districts. The tocsin was rung at Narbonne. The people rushed into the streets anu began erecting barricades, but desisted by request of the ex-Mayor, M. Perron 1, one of the leaders in the agitation, who said that he did not want bloodshed ami that he would surrender to justice. (Router)

M. Ferroul was arrested at dawn and removed to Montpellier There was no disturbance in the town which was overwhelmingly occupied by troops An imposing military force has gone to Argelliers for the purpose of arresting M. Albert, the principal leader in the agitation. The town is surrounded by peasant sentries on horses and cycles in order to notify the approach of the enemy. An infantry regiment at Aurillac has mutinied, the men singing the Internationale. It has, however, been suppressed. The mutiny at Larzao is denied.

The greatest sympathy is expressed for the distress in the South, but it is pointed out that the insurrection cannot relieve the glutted condition of the wine market, which is the cause (if the trouble. (Reuter)

Mr Ferroul has been arrested. The disturbers stoned his escort. The Cuirassiers charged and during the charge the Colonel was wounded. In the evening the peasants tried to set tire to the door of the sub-prefector. After long effort's they were dispersed by the police. (Havas)
Three agitators from Argeliers have been arrested. The police force is seeking Mr. Marcelin Albert. (Havas)

Replying to the toast of the Burgomaster of Charlottenburg, who referred to Waterloo, the Lord Mayor of London dwelt on the changes timp has wrought. France was now, he said, our staunchest friend. He expressed the hope that the three great nations would dwell together in amity. (Reuter)
The "Gymnote' has been wrecked. The damages are considerable. (Havas)
The speech from the throne to the Reiehsrath traces the patriotic role of the Chamber to the beginning of universal suffrage. ( Havas)
500 troops have mutinied at Kieff. The disorder has been suppressed. A Captain has been killed and 63 men killed or wounded by a fusillade between the mutineers and other troops. . (Reuter)
500 soldiers have mutinied. (Havas)

The Tsar acknowledging the thanks of the reactionary "Union of the Russian People" for the dissolution of the Duma, replied : "May the Union be my firm support, and be an example to everybody for loyalty and order." (Reuter)
The Ascot Gold Cup was stolen during the racing whilst the attention of the police constable and assistant in charge was diverted. (Renter)
Ascot. 1. Laity; 2. Andover; 3. Mains.
24 ran. Won by half a length. Three lengths between second and third. "Betting : 100 to 6 Lully : 13 to 2 Andover; 100 to 6 Malna. (Reuter)
Sussex beat Yorkshire by 65 runs. Surrey beat Cambridge University by 8 wickets.
Northamptonshire beat Hampshire by 23 runs. The South Africans boat Warwickshire by 276 runs.
Middlesex beat Kent by 10 wickets.
The following matches have been drawn : Notts v. Essex, and Lancashire v. Worcestershire. (Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The money market

Stock Exchange Pay-Day requirements caused a fairly strong demand for money, but there was no difficulty in obtaining all the accomodation that was required. The general rate for day-to-day money was 3 ½ per cent was obtained by bankers. The rate for three months' bills was firm at 3, 11/16

The weakness of the Paris exchange is a prominent feature in the present situation, and it is feared that this will have the effect of attracting still more gold from New York. The Bank of England is, however, in a very strong position, and the outlook gives cause for an optomistic view of things. The return this week shows an increase of 437,000 pounds in the reserve, which now stands at not less than 24,618,000 pounds while, the proportion to liabilities is up to 47 percent. "Other" deposits have increased by nearly one million and Other Securities are 440,000 pounds up.
The quotation for bar gold is somewhat easier, being now 779 ¾
Silver
The silver market is quiet, and the price, 30, 13/16 is unchanged on the week.
The Stock Markets

It would be idle to minimise the effect of the financial trouble in Egypt upon the stock markets here, for this has been felt more or less in most sections. On the other hand, it is equally futile to regardthis unsettles state of affairs as anything more than a passing phase, and in the informed circles this is the view which finds most favour. The present upset has caused no surprise, for it was recognised that the wild spectulation which had been going on during last winter would be inevitably followed by a reaction, and those who are suffering the most are these rash speculators to whon we refer. That they country will come through the crisis, and be better for it, there can be no manner of doubt, for the real basis of Egypt's prosperity is, and can be, in no way affected by these disturbances. On the other hand, the weeding out of the unsatisfactory features is a matter of much satisfaction. No better evidence of the confidence in Egyptian securities which is entertained by the best financial houses here could be desired than the fact that they are now buying up these at the present low prices as lock-up investments, and no one whose opinion is worth considering entertains any manner of doubt that their far-seeing policy will be amply rewarded.

As is usual when there is little business forthcoming, the rumours of failures in Egypt yesterday were much exaggerated, and prices slumped heavily in consequence, but a more confident tone has since been established, and an early recovery is now expected.
Consols.

The gilt-edged market was much harder early in the week, and Consols recovered some of their previos heavy loss. Yesterday they touched 84 1/8 for the account, but eased off in the afternoon, and closed at 84. They leave off tonight at 83 7/8 showing a further decline of 1/8. Last Friday we quoted them 83 ¾.
Foreign Bonds.

A disturbing influence in this section has been the race trouble between Japan and America in California, and this has had the effect of putting Japanese issues down. The reports of the complications have been much exaggerated in both be American and Japan, ese sensational press, and it is satisfactory to note from a cable this morning that the authorities' at Tokio have issued a warning to editors there that warlike articles on the situation, such as have been given much prominence during the last week or two, are forbidden. This is a wise step to take, as the evil results of thèse inflnmatory statements cannot be overestimated.
Japanese stocks were rather firmer yesterday. although at the close the 5 per cent. 1895-6 showed a loss 1/8 at 101, and both series of 4 ½ per cents. 1/8 at 94 7/8 and 93 7/8.
To-day Japanese have received support, and most of the stocks leave of with a-rise of.
Russians were bouyant at the beginning of the week, but have since shown a considerable easing off. The Fives are now quoted 82 1/8 and the Fours 73 3/4.
Homo Ralls.

It is announced that the directors of the various metropolitan railways have come to an agreement regarding the raising of fares which it is expected will shortly he put into effect. The decision has not caused any surprise, as it had been evident for a long time past that, with the increasing competition of County Council trainways and motor buses, a revision of fares was absolutely necessary if the railways were to be run as paying concerns.

On the face of it, it would seem that the companies by this latest move are playing still further into the hands of the motor bus companies, but there is good reason for supposing that, in the near future, the latter will also be compelled to increase their charges to the public, in consequence of the heavy losses they have suffered in substituting the more expensive petrol-driven Inis for the old horse-bus.
The above announcement gave a firm tone to the market, and the shares of the Metropolitan and Central London had a sharp advance, the former gaining 4£ and "Tubes". Other shares moved up in sympathy.
Yesterday the market was easier and although Central London managed to sustain a further advance of A at 74, Districts gave way A to H i after being 12. and Metropolitans to 42.
Southern Deferred stocks were weak at declines of it. To-day home rails display a het-tei tendency, but prices have moved irregularly.
Americans.

The flatness of the market in New York has kept movements in American shares here within narrow limits, and the tone has for the most part been irregular. Yesterday in Wall Street was the quietest session experienced for two years, no more than 189,000 shares changing hands. Our market started well above parity, hut fell away in the afternoon. At the close, however, a few advances were marked, notably 2 in Chesapeake and Ohio and Illinois Central, and 3/8 in Southern Pacific and Ait- chi.snn. Southern Railway Preference were marked down 2, but in the main the declines were fractional.
The movements to-day have generally been adverse. Unions are 1 lower hut Southern Preference have gained 2.
Egyptians

We have had a very wild and fluctuating market in Egyptians during the past week, and prices yesterday were very flat on rumours if failures in Cairn and Alexandria. To-day, however, there has been a substantial recovery all round.

National Bank suffered most yesterday and fell rapidly to 19, which is the lowest point touched for a very long time. To-day they closent 20. Agricultural Bank were also flat, and went down to they recovered to 7, 9/16 bid. They are now 7 J, and the Preference 9.L Daira Sanieli are quoted 13-14, and the Deferred 65-75 nominal.

Delta Preference Bearer fell from 10 to 9] sellers, but have to-day recovered to 9i. Delta land and Investment are supposed to. Egyptian Estates were dealt in nt 15/16, 3/32, and 1 yesterday, but are tonight 1. Union Foncière are steady at 4-5, and Corporation of Western Egypt
land Bank of Egypt are nominally of, and New Egyptian ij-$. Shares such as Egyptian Markets and Salt and Soda are quite unmentioned, and close 1 5/16 respect lively.

The fall in value of the really good shares -such as National Bank, Agricultural Bank, and Delta Preference, is attracting the attention of investors, and there is steady buying going on by all the best brokers, whose clients are locking away these shares. As soon as the forced liquidation ceases, a very sharp rebound all-round is anticipated.
Mining.

The mining market has fairly successfully resisted the influence of the depression jn other sections, although yesterday there was some falling away in prices. Business has of course lieen on a small scale throughout, one reason for this being the feeling of uncertainty regarding the future policy of the Transvasl Government on the labour question, which is to be announced by General Botha to-day. The general opinionm however is that the patriation of the Chinese will be commenced at the earliest possible date.
There has not been much business done in Kaffirs today. Rand mines clase at 5 ¾, also of 1/32, but East Rands are 1/8 better at 4 1/8.

There is nothing new to report with regard to Egyptian mining shares, which are still ignored by the public. Nile Valley are unchanged on the week, at 1-s but Egyptian Mines Exploration are a little better at 2.

div.head: REPORT ON THE CONGO
div.p: KING LEOPOLD'S REGIME
BRUSSELS, Saturday.
Telegraphing under date of the 8th inst. the Brussels correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" says –

The Congo Free Staff published yesterday an extensive report dealing with the entire situation of its affairs. This document, which is somewhat bulky, as it covers some 300 pages of the "Bulletin Official" of the State, is meant to he an answer to the desire expressed by the Belgian Parliamentary Committee now inquiring into the conditions of the annexation ol the Congo, for some reliable information concerning the State. The report is addressed by the three general secretaries of the Congo administration to the King-Sovereign, and is in tone and in wording nothing but a respectful eulogy of the Leopoldian régime. I cannot undertake to analyse it completely, all the more as it includes much that, is not new. I will only dwell here on the pointa which may have some (tearing on the future political issues of the Congo question.

First of all, the report sets out os a principle that, the King is the creator of the Congo State, and that he has the right to dispose of his creation as he chooses. Further, dealing with the "Domaine de la Couronne," that immense area of land which the King wants to exempt from any control for his personal interest, the report says that it is a lawful intitution, and that his Majesty is entitled to dispose of its revenues as a recognition of his personal sacrifices of past years. This contention is not new, but although it is once more expounded with much adroitness, it. will never lie adopted by the Belgian Parliament

With regard to the general politics of the State, and more especially to its financial policy, the report entirely npproves what has lieen dona The finanças of the State are most satisfactory, the labour tax gives good results, the Congo State has been worthy of its task, and so forth. But this report would, as a whole, lie rather uninteresting if its writers and its inspirera had not in the last pnrt of the document adopted an aggressive attitude and a polemical tone entirely inconsistent with the object of the report.. The document was meant originally to give some information to a Parliamentary Committee. The report now- before us is partly an obscure and unconvinc ing panegyrie of Congo rule, partly a fierce uttack, written in a language and tone which might he expected from a third class newspaper directed against all those who have hitherto failed to find that the Congo was an earthly Paradise. The recent report of his Britannic Majesty's consuls in the Congo are also assailed, and some extracts from these documents are published with comments intended to mislead those for whom the report is written as regards the motives of the British consuls.

In fact, this "official" report may be termed a desperate attempt by its authors to convey a favourable idea of the Congo. It is, as the French say, "de la poudre aux yeux." The report finally gives some interesting information as to the mining possibilities of the Congo, where great petroleum deposits and extensive tin and copper mines have been discovered.
Brussels, Sunday Night.

The report published on Friday by the Congo administration has met with an unsympathetic reception from the Belgian Press except the papers inspired or subsidised by the Free State. This morning the "Gazette" gives pro minence to a communication from Professor Cattier, a well-known authority on Colonial matters, wherein he gives a list, a lengthy one indeed, of the shortcomings and "forgotten things" of the report. Three items in the Congolese problem, he says, are essential for the Belgian Parliament to consider, viz., the financial situation of the State, the question of native taxation, and that of the "Crown Domaine." The report is utterly devoid of any information on these vital matters.

The "Dernière Heure" says that the repon uses 260 pages to say nothing at all, and that it is merely flinging dust into the eyes of the public to prevent them from seeing anything. Even the sane Conservative newspapers express the same view.

In my own opinion this "whitewashing" report will not. do much to hasten the solution of the annexation problem. The Parliamentary Committee cannot, be expected to proceed with their labours with such little information as is handed to them. New questions will and must be asked, and the Congo State will have to answer them. Belgium is "willing to annex the State, and intends to escape none of her duties, but she cannot be expected to take over with the Congo a financial burden of the extent of which she is absolutely ignorant.

div.head: A STORK'S DEVOTION
div.p: The devotion of a stork to its young was exemplified at Basle the other day. The nest was set on fire by a spark from a chimney, but the mother bird refused to leave the fledglings, and all were burned to death.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: Le 22 Juin 1907 de 9 h a.m. a 1 h p.m. Municiparlite procedera a la vente auxencheres publiques pres du fort No. 20 de Kom-El-Chougafa El Barrani d'une quantite de 600 metres cubes environ de pierres aiusi que d'une quantite de vieux bois, etc. provenant de la demolition.
Ces pierres sont divisees en lots de 20 a 100 m 3

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'encheres de 1 % et deposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetee au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement integral la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.

Ils auront a supporter les droits de carriere an profit de la ville et devront enlever les pierres achetees dansun delai de (10) dix jours sous peine de folle enchere pour compte de l'Adjudicataire et sous perte du depot de 10%
La Municipalite est libre de ne pas conner suite a l'adjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts.
Alexandrie, le 15 Juin 1907
AVIS

Les 25 Juin 1907 de 9 h. a.m 1 h. p.m la Municipalite procedera a la vente aux encheres publiques pres de l'ex jardin francaise d'une quantite de pierres et de vieux bois provenant de la demolition du dit jardin
Ces pierres sont divisees en lots de 20 a 100 m 3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'encheres de 1 % et deposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetee au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement integral la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.

Ils auront a supporter les droits de carriere an profit de la ville et devront enlever les pierres achetees dansun delai de (10) dix jours sous peine de folle enchere pour compte de l'Adjudicataire et sous perte du depot de 10%
La Municipalite est libre de ne pas conner suite a l'adjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts.
Alexandrie, le 15 Juin 1907

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: There was stolen yesterday by an employée in the office of Messrs. Moursi Brothers well known cotton merchants of this city the sum of £600 sterling in National Bank Notes, amongst them being five notes of L.E. 100 each bearing the following numbers, 18,136, 28,882, 30,259, 30,260, and 30,740. It is requested that in case any of these notes are presented, information will be given immediately to the Alexandria City Police, who are actively engaged on the case. The notes have been stopped at the Bank. 30491-10-2
